description: Creates a subscriber for accounts that are already enabled in Amazon Security Lake. You can create a subscriber with access to data in the current Amazon Web Services Region.

parameters.name: accessTypes
parameters.description: The Amazon S3 or Lake Formation access type. (string) ---

parameters.name: sources
parameters.description: The supported Amazon Web Services services from which logs and events are collected. Security Lake supports log and event collection for natively supported Amazon Web Services services. (dict) --- The supported source types from which logs and events are collected in Amazon Security Lake. For a list of supported Amazon Web Services services, see the Amazon Security Lake User Guide. awsLogSource (dict) --- Amazon Security Lake supports log and event collection for natively supported Amazon Web Services services. For more information, see the Amazon Security Lake User Guide. sourceName (string) --- The name for a Amazon Web Services source. This must be a Regionally unique value. sourceVersion (string) --- The version for a Amazon Web Services source. customLogSource (dict) --- Amazon Security Lake supports custom source types. attributes (dict) --- The attributes of a third-party custom source. crawlerArn (string) --- The ARN of the Glue crawler. databaseArn (string) --- The ARN of the Glue database where results are written, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*. tableArn (string) --- The ARN of the Glue table. provider (dict) --- The details of the log provider for a third-party custom source. location (string) --- The location of the partition in the Amazon S3 bucket for Security Lake. roleArn (string) --- The ARN of the IAM role to be used by the entity putting logs into your custom source partition. Security Lake will apply the correct access policies to this role, but you must first manually create the trust policy for this role. The IAM role name must start with the text --Security Lake'. The IAM role must trust the logProviderAccountId to assume the role. sourceName (string) --- The name for a third-party custom source. sourceVersion (string) --- The version for a third-party custom source. This must be a Regionally unique value.

nested_params.name: awsLogSource
nested_params.description: Amazon Security Lake supports log and event collection for natively supported Amazon Web Services services. For more information, see the Amazon Security Lake User Guide.

nested_params.description: The name for a Amazon Web Services source. This must be a Regionally unique value.

nested_params.name: sourceVersion
nested_params.description: The version for a Amazon Web Services source. This must be a Regionally unique value.

nested_params.name: customLogSource
nested_params.description: Amazon Security Lake supports custom source types. For more information, see the Amazon Security Lake User Guide.

nested_params.name: attributes
nested_params.description: The attributes of a third-party custom source.

nested_params.name: crawlerArn
nested_params.description: The ARN of the Glue crawler.

nested_params.name: databaseArn
nested_params.description: The ARN of the Glue database where results are written, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*.

nested_params.name: tableArn
nested_params.description: The ARN of the Glue table.

nested_params.name: provider
nested_params.description: The details of the log provider for a third-party custom source.

nested_params.name: location
nested_params.description: The location of the partition in the Amazon S3 bucket for Security Lake.

nested_params.name: roleArn
nested_params.description: The ARN of the IAM role to be used by the entity putting logs into your custom source partition. Security Lake will apply the correct access policies to this role, but you must first manually create the trust policy for this role. The IAM role name must start with the text --Security Lake'. The IAM role must trust the logProviderAccountId to assume the role.

nested_params.name: sourceName
nested_params.description: The name for a third-party custom source. This must be a Regionally unique value.

nested_params.name: sourceVersion
nested_params.description: The version for a third-party custom source. This must be a Regionally unique value.

parameters.name: subscriberIdentity
parameters.description: The Amazon Web Services identity used to access your data. The external ID used to establish trust relationship with the Amazon Web Services identity. The Amazon Web Services identity principal.

nested_params.name: externalId
nested_params.description: The external ID used to establish trust relationship with the Amazon Web Services identity.

nested_params.name: principal
nested_params.description: The Amazon Web Services identity principal.

parameters.name: subscriberName
parameters.description: The name of your Security Lake subscriber account.

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: An array of objects, one for each tag to associate with the subscriber. For each tag, you must specify both a tag key and a tag value. A tag value cannot be null, but it can be an empty string. (dict) --- A tag is a label that you can define and associate with Amazon Web Services resources, including certain types of Amazon Security Lake resources. Tags can help you identify, categorize, and manage resources in different ways, such as by owner, environment, or other criteria. You can associate tags with the following types of Security Lake resources: subscribers, and the data lake configuration for your Amazon Web Services account in individual Amazon Web Services Regions. A resource can have up to 50 tags. Each tag consists of a required tag key and an associated tag value. A tag key is a general label that acts as a category for a more specific tag value. Each tag key must be unique and it can have only one tag value. A tag value acts as a descriptor for a tag key. Tag keys and values are case sensitive. They can contain letters, numbers, spaces, or the following symbols: _ . : / = + @ - For more information, see Tagging Amazon Security Lake resources in the Amazon Security Lake User Guide. The name of the tag. This is a general label that acts as a category for a more specific tag value ( value). The value that's associated with the specified tag key ( key). This value acts as a descriptor for the tag key. A tag value cannot be null, but it can be an empty string.

nested_params.name: key
nested_params.description: The name of the tag. This is a general label that acts as a category for a more specific tag value ( value).

nested_params.name: value
nested_params.description: The value that's associated with the specified tag key ( key). This value acts as a descriptor for the tag key. A tag value cannot be null, but it can be an empty string.

nested_items.name: subscriber
nested_items.description: Retrieve information about the subscriber created using the CreateSubscriber API.

nested_items.name: accessTypes
nested_items.description: You can choose to notify subscribers of new objects with an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue or through messaging to an HTTPS endpoint provided by the subscriber.
(string) ---

nested_items.description: The date and time when the subscriber was created.

nested_items.name: resourceShareArn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) which uniquely defines the Amazon Web Services RAM resource share. Before accepting the RAM resource share invitation, you can view details related to the RAM resource share.

nested_items.name: resourceShareName
nested_items.description: The name of the resource share.

nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the role of the subscriber.
